2432.20.text: If all the nomadic tribes on earth can be said to have one thing in common, then it is their hospitality.

2474.12.text: Of the four hundred Kazakhs it is calculated continue to practice hunting in this region,

2478.72.text: seventy two of them have decided to enter the competition,

2481.72.text: some of them coming from over three hundred kilometres away.

2484.76.text: A long journey, but then, this is a very special occasion.

2499.64.text: They all come dressed in their coats, called chapan,

2501.96.text: and the characteristic caps of silk and wolf fur, which are called kepesh.

2511.24.text: The fact is very little has changed in the life

2513.92.text: of these Muslim herdsmen since the end of the seventeenth century

2516.88.text: when they settled in this corner of Mongolia, fleeing from tribal wars.

2523.92.text: A century later, after a number of devastating incursions,

2526.88.text: lead by a Manchu emperor, and which annihilated the Mongols of the region,

2530.88.text: the Kazakhs gained control of this harsh, extreme land.

2539.88.text: Today, and because they are isolated by the Altai mountains and the river Hovd,

2543.08.text: these hunters have been able to preserve their language,

2546.00.text: their cultural traditions, and their identity as Kazakhs.

2553.48.text: A common characteristic among them are the owl feathers

2557.12.text: that decorate their kepesh, the thin black stripes of which represent the verses of the Koran,

2561.84.text: a kind of lucky charm that protects them and brings them good luck during the hunt.

2568.84.text: The tomaga, the hood that covers the head of the eagle,

2572.96.text: is also decorated with silver incrustations,

2575.60.text: a sign that the owner is not doing too badly in life.

2589.04.text: In a region as large as Belgium,

2591.64.text: and with just 90,000 inhabitants, social occasions are rare,

2595.44.text: and so today is a magnificent opportunity to get together,

2599.36.text: meet old friends and bring yourself up to date on other people’s lives.

2611.04.text: The atmosphere inside the gers is extremely animated.

2614.08.text: Gathered around in many different groups,

2616.52.text: the hunters recount a thousand and one battles of their days out hunting.

2620.36.text: After all, though we are in a remote corner of the planet,

2623.76.text: they are hunters, and we all know what hunters are like…

2649.08.text: With so many people, it’s also a good chance to practice Kuk Ber,

2652.84.text: a very popular game in Central Asia,

2655.24.text: which the Kazakhs have been playing since time immemorial.

2669.48.text: Prohibited during the Soviet era, Kuk Ber  has virtually no rules,

2674.32.text: though in each country it is played in a different way.

2676.76.text: The Kazakhs compete in pairs, and the entire game consists

2680.48.text: of getting hold of a sheep or goat skin.

2682.80.text: At the end, the winner leaves the skin on the ground for the other competitors to fight over.

2693.56.text: Kuk Ber is normally played at weddings.

2697.16.text: At the end of the celebration, when everyone has had plenty of vodka to drink,

2701.08.text: the bride’s father throws a skin onto the ground,

2703.76.text: and the person that manages to carry it to the ger of the bride’s parents will receive a prize – a yak.

2709.72.text: The difficulty is not just fighting against the other guests –

2713.12.text: often, the bride’s house is so far away that the game can go on for several hours…

2717.80.text: but a yak is a prize well worth fighting for.

2773.80.text: The day of the competition dawns clear and sunny.

2783.40.text: Since the first light of morning,

2786.12.text: the participants have been taking up their positions at the top of a hill.

2789.64.text: A certain nervousness can be felt in the air,

2793.20.text: and not only because it is the first time that so many hunter have come together to test their skill,

2798.44.text: but also because yesterday, inside the gers,

2801.20.text: many bets were laid, and some may have yet rather too much.

2813.68.text: The first part of the competition consists of releasing the eagles,

2817.68.text: one by one, on the signal of a pennant, towards a fox skin pulled along by a horse.

2833.64.text: The five birds of prey that take least time to reach the fox skin

2837.64.text: will go into the final, where this time the target  will be a live fox.

2874.28.text: Evening is drawing in, and the five finalists are ready for

2877.88.text: the grand final. Kumarkán, the master hunter, is one of them.

2943.64.text: The competition has ended, and the participants go to collect their eagles.

2956.00.text: Kumarkan was not the winner, but he doesn’t mind too much.

2958.88.text: Next year, he will return with his son Talaikán and his friends,

2964.12.text: to once again share an art and a tradition which here remains alive,

2968.48.text: but which unfortunately in his homeland, neighbouring Kazakhstan, died out long ago.

2979.48.text: With no noisy farewells, and more or less in silence,

2982.16.text: the hunters slowly leave Jorjok and head out into their world

2985.76.text: of infinite spaces and vast horizons.

2999.76.text: In the Gobi desert, in the middle of October,

3001.92.text: the grass is drying. For the Tansendarya clan,

3006.32.text: it is time to gather up camp and set off towards less harsh lands in which to spend the winter.

3019.08.text: The cattle and part of the family left at daybreak,

3021.88.text: while the rest have remained, loading the camels and organising the caravan.

3033.44.text: For eight days they will walk, moving northwest to the edge of the desert.

3037.60.text: Then, at the start of spring, they will travel up into the highlands of the steppe,

3043.88.text: only to return later to the Gobi.

3046.24.text: That is what their ancestors did, that is what they do,

3050.56.text: and that is what their children will do.

3058.24.text: And that is the story of three ethnic groups that live in a world of constant movement,

3062.96.text: struggling to preserve their most valuable treasure, their culture,

3068.40.text: is being wiped out by a society engaged in a headlong rush towards globalisation.
